Introduction

Recognition of a patient's wishes regarding organ donation and discussion with nominated representatives was highlighted as part of End of Life Care Pathways in the Department of Health End of Life Care Strategy, published in
Consideration of organ and tissue donation should form a usual part of best practice in end of life (EOL) care planning.

The recommendations made in 2008 included the introduction of an organ donation committee, led by a clinician, specialist nurse and a lay chairperson. In 2013 The ‘Taking Organ Transplantation to 2020 UK Strategy' was published. This built on the changes initiated inThe aim of the strategy was to ‘pursue consistently excellent practice in the care of every potential donor and maximise the use of every available organ'. The strategy was aimed at raising awareness of donation, increasing discussion with family members, consideration of organ donation as part of routine end of life care and improved transplantation processes including more sustainable training and development.

Despite a 50% increase in donation rates and a 30.5% increase in transplants by 2013 there continues to be patients who die while awaiting transplants. There are currently around 6,000 people on the active transplant list in the UK and every day across the UK, someone dies waiting for a transplant because of a shortage of organ donors.

In England 80% of people support donation but only 37% had registered their wishes (gov.com, Feb 2020) and this means families are often left with a difficult decision when a loved one dies. Following public consultation, the Organ Donation (Deemed Consent) Bill received Royal Assent on the th March 2019 and was passed in to law on the 20th May 2020. This means that all competent adults who are freely resident in England for >1 year will be considered as potential donors unless they specifically chose to opt out or are excluded. Under the law donation will still be discussed with families to ensure that the most up to date individual wishes are known and respected.

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (Mid South Essex NHS FT) recognises the need to maximise the opportunities for donation in support of individuals wishes and embraces the acceptance of donation as an integral part of all EOL care in appropriate areas across the Trust.

It is to be noted that at the time of publication of this policy there has been a recent merger of Basildon and Thurrock University Hospital, Southend University Hospital and Broomfield Hospital into the Mid South Essex NHS FT. However, it remains that there are three separate CLODs and Organ Donation Committees, one each at Basildon and Thurrock University Hospital, Southend University Hospital and Broomfield Hospital. This policy is promoting collaborative working between the CLODs and Committees as it should also be noted that a single 6-monthly Organ Donation Trust Report will be produced for Mid South Essex NHS FT to cover all three hospitals and the Donor Recognition Funds will be paid into a single account.
Scope

This policy is designed to ensure that every patient who dies in the care of the Mid South Essex NHS FT is considered (where appropriate) for organ and/or tissue donation and that an organisational process is in place to support donation activity. It should be standard practice that every effort will be undertaken to support organ donation, taking into account the individual needs and preferences of patients and their families and that logistics should not be allowed to obstruct this unless under extreme circumstances.

This policy applies to all patients in Critical Care and the Emergency Department who meets the criteria for organ donation as summarised in this document. This document will clarify understanding across the Trust on issues surrounding practice in organ and tissue donation and will integrate the role of Specialist Nurses for Organ Donation (SN-OD) and Specialist Requester (SR) who are key in establishing and facilitating organ and tissue donation in clinical practice.

The policy will recognise the complexities that arise owing to the majority of potential organ donors lacking the capacity to be directly involved in decision making at the time of their death. It will clarify processes to ensure the legal, ethical and professional compliance of Mid South Essex NHS FT staff.
This policy should be implemented in light of the Mid South Essex NHS FT duty to avoid unlawful discrimination and with regard to the promotion of equal opportunity. This will be done by:
Ensuring that the consideration of organ and tissue donation will become a normal part of end of life / bereavement care.

Ensuring that all staff recognise their duty of care in relation to establishing the wishes of every patient with regard to organ/tissue Donation, whether by discussion with their family or via the NHS Organ Donor Register held by NHS Blood and Transplant (NHSBT) and accessed via the Specialist Nurses/ Specialist Requester
Training Trust staff to identify and refer all potential organ and tissue donors to a Specialist Nurse for Organ Donation (SN-OD), Specialist Requester (SR) or Tissue Services.
Ensuring all potential donor families to be approached and offered organ and tissue donation where there is no medical or social contraindication to such an approach.
Ensuring that whenever possible a donation specialist is directly involved in any family approach regarding donation alongside the Trust staff.
Open and sensitive communication if donation cannot be facilitated where individuals are not suitable for donation and the next of kin or significant other raises the subject.
All communication with the next of kin / significant others is accurately documented in the potential donor's case notes in accordance with Trust and National / EU standards.
Optimal clinical management of any potential donor in the most appropriate location, to ensure that organs and tissues remain viable for transplantation.
Providing a comprehensive reference document in support of the organ donation process.
Definitions
Brain Stem

This is the important site in the human brain responsible for maintaining breathing, heart rate, blood pressure, and level of consciousness. The brain stem connects the spinal cord to the brain and relays all vital information between the body and the brain.
Brain Stem Death

This is the irreversible loss of the capacity for consciousness combined with irreversible loss of the capacity to breathe'. (DoH 1998) This is considered to be incompatible with life and therefore death is diagnosed. See Neurological determination of death.
CLOD (Clinical Lead – Organ Donation)

Clinical Lead for Organ Donation is a senior doctor based in a hospital trust who provides clinical leadership to champion organ donation. In conjunction with the SN- OD and the organ donation committee, their role is to implement national guidelines, maximise donation potential and provide advice, support and education on all donation issues.
Deemed Consent

The Deemed Consent Act (also known as “Opt out”) means that, in England, all individuals over  are considered potential organ and tissue donors after death, unless they make a decision about organ donation, they have nominated a representative to make a decision on their behalf after death or they are an excepted adult.
DBD (Donation after Brainstem Death)

Donation after Brain-stem Death refers to the retrieval of organs and tissue for the purposes of transplantation after death that is confirmed using neurological criteria (brain-stem death). Diagnosis of brain stem death is laid down in the Code of Practice for Diagnosis and Confirmation of Death (AoMRC 2008). This was previously known as Heart Beating Donation (HBD). In keeping with current terminology, this form of donation will be known as DBD in this document.
DCD (Donation after Circulatory Death)

Donation after Circulatory Death refers to the retrieval of organs and tissue for the purposes of transplantation after death that is confirmed using 'traditional' cardio- respiratory criteria, as laid down in Code of Practice for Diagnosis and Confirmation of Death (AoMRC 2008). This was previously known as non-heart beating donation (NHBD). In keeping with current terminology, this form of donation will be known as DCD in this document.

This pathway refers exclusively to 'controlled' DCD - donation which follows a cardiac death that is the result of the withdrawal or non-escalation of cardio- respiratory support therapies that are considered to be no longer in a patient's best interests. Maastricht Category III: 'Awaiting Cardiac Arrest', and Maastricht Category IV: 'Cardiac Arrest in a Brain Stem Dead Donor' (AoMRC 2008)
Donation following sudden cardiac death, for example after unsuccessful resuscitation attempts, is not currently supported in the UK.
Donor Family

The term donor family is used generically to refer to the family and friends of longstanding. For the purposes of obtaining consent this must include the nominated representative or in their absence the person in the highest qualifying relationship as stated by the Human Tissue Act (2004).
Human Tissue Act

The Human Tissue Act (2004) implemented st September 2006 covers England, Wales and Northern Ireland and was introduced to regulate activities concerning the removal, storage, use and disposal of human tissue. Amended regulations: Human

Tissue (permitted material: exceptions) Regulations 2020 were implemented on th May 2020 and extend to England only with respect of transplantation. The Human Tissue Act repeals and replaces the Human Tissue Act 1961, the Anatomy Act 1984 and the Human Organ Transplants Act 1989
Human Tissue Authority
The Human Tissue Act (2004) establishes the Human Tissue Authority to act as the regulating body for all matters concerning the donation of organs and tissues for transplantation.
Nominated Representative

Adults may nominate one or more people to represent them after death over the issue of consent for the removal, storage and use of organs and tissues for transplantation. A nominated representative may be appointed orally in the presence of two witnesses or in writing with a witness attesting the signature. A nominated representative will take precedence over a person in a qualifying relationship.
Neurological Determination of Death

(AoMRC 2008; Pellegrino 2010; Gardiner, Shemie et al. 2012) Death is considered to be a state in which an individual has simultaneously and irreversibly lost both the capacity for consciousness and the capacity to breathe.

Neurological determination of death refers to a clinical state that is frequently referred to as brain-stem death or simply brain death. The UK criteria are based upon the premise that irreversible and complete loss of brain-stem function is sufficient of itself to result in the irreversible loss of the capacity to breathe and the capacity for consciousness, and hence use the term brain-stem death. However, guidance in many other parts of the world (e.g. North America, Australia) is concerned with whole brain death, and uses the term brain death.
NHS Blood and Transplant
NHS Blood and Transplant (NHSBT) is a joint England & Wales Special Health Authority within the NHS responsible for managing the National Blood Service and UK Transplantation services.
National Organ Retrieval Service (NORS)

This is a UK-wide network of dedicated Organ Retrieval Teams that aim to ensure timely, high quality organ removal from all deceased donors. Organ retrieval teams are not provided by Mid South Essex NHS FT and will be the closest team available to the donor hospital however can be mobilised from any transplant centre in the UK that is commissioned to provide a NORS.
Organ Donor Register (ODR)

The NHS Organ Donor Register is a confidential computerised database managed by UK Transplant which holds details of people who have registered their wishes regarding organ donation in the event of their death. This includes preference to become an organ donor (“opt-in”) and the preference not to donate organs (“opt- out”).
Organ Donation Committee (ODC)

The Organ Donation Committee monitors and identify barriers to donation within the Trust. Key stakeholders from within the Trust and NHS Blood and Transplant attend quarterly meetings to review donation activity and plan necessary interventions.
Qualifying Relationship
In the absence of a nominated representative, the Human Tissue Act 2004 ranks persons in a qualifying relationship for the purpose of obtaining consent.
a) Spouse or partner (including civil or same sex partner)
b) Parent or child (in this context a ‘child' can be any age)
c) Brother or sister
d) Grandparent or grandchild
e) Niece or nephew
f) Stepfather or stepmother
g) Half-brother or half sister
h) Friend of longstanding
The ranking is intended to help those seeking consent to know who to approach. Consent should be obtained from the person in the highest-ranking qualifying relationship.
Retrieval Team (NORS)

The retrieval team work as part of the National Organ Retrieval Service (NORS) to provide a specialist surgical team to the donor hospital. This surgical team will retrieve all consented organs in theatre.

Each team is virtually self-sufficient and will attend with all necessary equipment other than the standard equipment (see theatre guidelines below). They will require at least one Mid South Essex NHS FT staff member to support and guide them in the department. The teams are available  hours a day. NORS provide an abdominal and cardiothoracic team and may in special circumstances provide additional teams.
Specialist Nurse Organ Donation (SN-OD)

A specialist in donor care working locally within the ICU responsible for leading donation practice providing advice, support and education on all donation issues. They will obtain written consent for donation from the family or friends of long standing. The SNOD also fulfils an on-call commitment to the Eastern Region and is employed by NHS Blood and Transplant.
Specialist Nurse Organ Donation- Specialist Requester (SNOD-SR)

A SNOD with additional training in the family approach process. The SR focuses on assessing suitability of the potential donor, supporting the family through EOL conversations and decisions, and requesting consent for Organ Donation. The SNOD-SR is not based at any local hospital, they are spread across several geographical locations in the Eastern to enable attendance at referrals in different hospitals. The SNOD-SR is employed by NHS Blood and Transplant
Solid Organs for Transplantation
In the UK, DCD and DBD programmes currently support the retrieval and transplantation of the following solid organs:-
Heart
Lungs
Kidney
Liver
Pancreas
Small bowel (stomach, ileum, jejunum, colon, abdominal wall, spleen)
Tissue Donation

Donation of Human tissue for transplantation takes place post-mortem, usually within the first 24 hours after death. Most patients can donate tissue after death. Retrieval of tissue is undertaken by specialist NHSBT retrieval teams and take place in the hospital mortuary or funeral directors. The team are accountable for the retrieval process and families are able to view the patient following donation.
Tissues that can be donated for transplantation are:
Eyes (Cornea and sclera)
Heart valves
Arteries
Skin
Bone
Tendon
Meniscus
Tissue Coordinator - National Referral Centre (Tissue Donation)

To make a referral for Tissue Donation contact the NHSBT National Referral Centre on 0800 432 0559. Between the hours of 8pm and 8am you will be asked to leave a message and a Specialist Nurse will call back. The Specialist Nurses will ask you for medical information about the patient, obtain consent from the family by phone and coordinate the retrieval process. Please ensure that the patients next of kin have been informed of death and that they are aware of the referral before calling.
Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Chief Executive:

The Chief Executive as the Accounting Officer has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust. In this respect, he/she is responsible for ensuring that the infrastructure required to support the delivery and implementation of this document is available. He/she will delegate the full implementation of this document to a relevant Executive Director.
Medical Director:

The Medical Director is responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all medical staff are able to comply with the contents of this document. In addition, he/she is responsible for ensuring that the monitoring and audit of this document is undertaken and reported in the appropriate forum as indicated in the document.
Director of Nursing:

The Director of Nursing is responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all non-medical staff (nurses, midwives and allied health professionals) are able to comply with the contents of this document.
Director of Operations:
The Director of Operations is responsible for ensuring that there are systems and processes in place to communicate and implement this document in the clinical areas.
Divisional Clinical Directors:

The Divisional Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that systems and processes are in place throughout the Divisions to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate. In addition, the Divisional Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that all medical and dental staff comply with the contents of the document.
Divisional General Managers:

The Divisional General Managers are responsible for implementing the systems and processes required throughout the Divisions to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate.
Heads of Nursing and Quality (HoNQ):
The HoNQs are responsible for ensuring that the policy is disseminated throughout the Division and that the required monitoring and audit are undertaken, with the resources provided to support this.
Clinical Service Unit Clinical Leads/ Unit Managers:

Clinical Service Unit Clinical Leads and Unit Managers are responsible for implementing this document in the Clinical Service Unit and for monitoring the impact on the service and reporting compliance with the document. They are accountable to the Divisional Clinical Director and General Manager in this respect.
Lead Nurses:

Lead Nurses are responsible for ensuring that all nursing staff (including Nurse Specialists, Practitioners/Advisors) within the Clinical Service Unit comply with the contents of this document and for taking action when this is not the case. The Lead Nurse will make sure that all necessary training is provided.
Medical Staff:
The Consultant holds ultimate responsibility for ensuring that all members of the medical team follow this document.
Senior Sisters/Nursing Staff:

The Senior Sister/nurse in charge is accountable for the safe care and management of a patient on the ward. They are therefore responsible for ensuring that all staff within the ward comply with this document and for implementing a system to provide assurance that this is the case.
The Clinical Lead for Organ Donation (CLOD):
Each Trust has a Clinical Lead for Organ Donation (CLOD) who is paid one PA (4 hours) per week to undertake the role on behalf of NHSBT.
The role includes:
Championing organ donation within the Trust and the local population
Setting up and assisting with the running of the Trust Organ Donation Committee
Leading on the implementation of policies and guidelines
Reporting to NHSBT and the Trust Board on all aspects of donation activity
Tackling issues relating to donation activities
Keeping the Trust updated on current practice in donation and transplantation
Education
The CLOD will receive support and training on all aspects of donation from NHSBT.
The Specialist Nurse for Organ Donation (SNOD):
Each Trust has a Specialist Nurse – Organ Donation (SN-OD), employed by NHSBT and possessing an honorary contract with the Trust. The SN-OD will be part of the Critical Care team. The role includes:
Working in-house to help encourage staff to see donation as part of all end-of- life decision-making
Speaking to families / next of kin regarding the possibility of organ donation
Coordinating the donor process
Supporting staff throughout the donation process and follow up post donation
Education / training for all staff involved in donation
Audit (national / local)
Reporting to the Trust / NHSBT / Divisions / Departments on all aspects of donation activity
Work in collaboration with the Macmillan/Palliative Care team and Bereavement Nurse Specialist.
Be a core member of the Trust's End of Life Strategy Group.
Working with the CLOD to Promote donation across the Trust and local population
To Keep the Trust updated with current practice o Tackle issues around donation activity
Maintaining a regional on-call commitment
Teaching / presenting externally for the Regional Team (universities, schools, public events e.g.)
Undertaking specific projects relating to organ donation for the Regional Team
Debriefing staff within 2 weeks of donation
The SN-OD will be given resource support and Trust-based mandatory training by the Trust and will receive all other support by NHSBT.
Procedures and actions to follow
Organ Donation Pathway
Organ donation should be considered as a usual part of ‘end-of-life care' planning.
All ventilated patients who are being considered for EOL Care should be assessed for organ donation potential. (GMC 2010).

It should be noted that there are very few absolute contraindications to organ donation and the criteria for acceptance changes frequently. In view of this it is recommended that ALL patients are discussed with the Specialist Nurse Organ Donation.
While recognising clinical situations vary, these patients are usually in two broad categories.
Following a Devastating Brain Injury and awaiting or confirmed brain stem death tests or;
Are in a situation where continued treatment is not in the patient's best interest, and a withdrawal of life sustaining treatment decision is being considered.

In order to allow full assessment of the suitability of any patient for donation and to facilitate the presence of a donation specialist in any family approach for organ donation, it is recommended that contact is made with the Organ Donation Services Team at the earliest possible opportunity (i.e. as soon as DDNC is suspected/anticipated or when withdrawal of life sustaining treatment is provisionally discussed by clinical staff). There is no requirement to discuss donation or other end of life provision with the family before referring to the Organ Donation Services Team. It is recommended that such discussions are avoided until a SN-OD / SR is involved and a collaborative approach can be taken. Early referral will ensure that where donation is a possibility, there are no unnecessary delays for both the donor's family and where donation is not possible families are not asked for consent unnecessarily.

Provided that delay is in the patient's overall best interests, life-sustaining treatments should not be withdrawn or limited until the patient's wishes around organ donation have been explored and the clinical potential for donation has been assessed in accordance with legal and professional guidance. Admission to ICU will allow confirmation of diagnosis, any donation potential to be realised and allow for the family to come to terms with the patient's diagnosis and prognosis.
Identifying patients who are potential organ donors (NICE CG135,
Updated 2016).

Identify all patients who are potentially suitable donors as early as possible, through a systematic approach. While recognising that clinical situations vary, identification should be based on either of the following criteria:
The absence of one or more cranial nerve reflexes and
A Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 4 or less that is not explained by sedation OR
A decision has been made to perform brain stem death tests
The healthcare team caring for the patient should initiate discussions about potential organ donation with the specialist nurse for organ donation.

Donation after brain stem death (DBD) may be possible: When no further treatment options are available or appropriate, and there is a plan to confirm death by neurological criteria (DDNC). The critical care team should notify the SNOD/SR either as soon as the decision is made to discontinue sedation/analgesia or immediately if the patient has never received sedation/analgesia. This notification should take place even if the critical care team believe that donation might be contra-indicated or inappropriate. This discussion will ensure that all options are considered, and that advice is available to the critical care team and potential donor's family.
Discussions about organ donation with the family should not occur before contacting the SNOD/SR and a collaborative approach should be supported.

Donation after circulatory death (DCD) may be possible: In the context of a catastrophic neurological injury which does not lead to brainstem death and / or a decision to withdraw treatment when no further treatment options are available or in the patient's best interests. Organ donation occurs after death has been confirmed using cardio-respiratory criteria for death.

The SNOD/SR should be notified as soon as the ICU team is considering withdrawal of life sustaining treatment.  This discussion will ensure that all options are considered, that advice is available to the critical care team and the potential donor's family and a collaborative approach is supported.
Referral to SNOD/SR
The SN-OD/SR must be notified according to NICE guidelines CG 135 (NICE 2011)
Contact the SN-OD/SR when the referral notification criteria are met.
(UK Organ Donor Referral Line

The SN-OD will return your call within 20 minutes (if not re-page once more). Unless spontaneously requested by the patient's family/next of kin, donation should not be discussed at this stage. Discussions with the SN-OD/SR must be initiated to allow for a full assessment of donation suitability.
This will include:
Consulting the NHS Organ Donor Register for registered decisions
Review of medical notes & any advanced statements or Lasting Power of Attorney for Health & Welfare.
An assessment of the families/next of kin's understanding of the diagnosis
This assessment is paramount before donation is discussed with the family.
On notification, the SN-OD/SR will typically ask for the following patient information. Staff should utilise the Organ Donation referral and post referral checklist. See Appendix A
Name
Date of birth
Post code
NHS number
Notifying clinician name, hospital and contact details
Primary diagnosis & Admission history
Supportive treatment including ventilation and cardiovascular support
Current blood results (including preadmission creatinine if available)
Past medical including active infections & virology
Past social history of note
Blood group
Next of Kin including location & understanding
Other immediately relevant family information
Approaching the family to offer the option of organ donation

In collaboration with the Consultant and/ or their designate, it is the responsibility of the SN-OD/SR to assess the appropriateness and timing of raising donation as determined by the patient's medical history and the family's ability to accept the diagnosis of brain stem death or withdrawal of treatment following a best interest's discussion. It may be appropriate to delay discussing donation until the family have had time to accept these issues. It must be noted that a premature approach to the family results in them declining the option of donation in a large proportion of cases. This can potentially lead to regrets later regarding their decision not to donate.

In addition to the information provided at the time of notification the SN-OD/SR will attend the Unit and carry out a detailed assessment of the potential for donation. This assessment will also establish a detailed medical, surgical and social history of the potential donor and consists of:
Review of medical records, including, if appropriate, from external healthcare providers
Review of laboratory and radiology results
Discussion with clinician with responsibility for patient
Discussion with MDT
Checking the Organ Donor Register
Age / past medical history
History of current admission
Next of kin and family details
Possible contra-indications
Cardiovascular status (use of inotropes / vasopressors)
Respiratory status (level of ventilatory support, inspired oxygen fraction)
Renal status
Whether a referral to the Coroner / Procurator Fiscal is required
Consider religious views and pastoral care, and if appropriate liaise with chaplaincy
It is the responsibility of the Consultant in charge of ICU to explain to the family/ next of kin:
Brain stem death or;
Decision of withdrawal of treatment in the patient's best interests
Best practice is a collaborative approach with the SN-OD/SR accompanying the ICU/Anaesthetic consultant in these meetings.
This is to ensure that a consistent message regarding the death is reinforced in all further discussions and to allow the SN-OD/SR to carry out an assessment of the family.

If felt appropriate by the SNOD/SR, and only once the family have demonstrated an understanding that death has occurred, in the case of DDNC, or that withdrawal of life sustaining treatment is in the patient's best interest, will donation be raised.

The ICU/Anaesthetic Consultant and the SN-OD/SR will determine the appropriate person to make the approach. The person that makes the approach must feel confident and have an understanding of organ and tissue donation. It is important that this person can devote time to supporting the decision-making process. (Burroughs, Hong et al. 1998; DeJong, Franz et al. 1998; Verble and Worth 2000; Sque, Long-Sutehall et al. 2003)
The families of all potential donors should have access to the specialist knowledge provided by the SN-OD/SR in the decision-making process. Ideally this will require face to face discussions.

The use of a collaborative approach i.e. joint approach between the ICU/Anaesthetic Consultant and the SN-OD/SR may provide the best situation for families to make an informed decision (UKTransplant 2003).

The SN-OD/SR is able to devote unlimited time to support the family and can provide appropriate information to answer immediate questions. It is recognised that any delay can have a detrimental effect on their experience (Sque, Long-Sutehall et al. 2003).
It is the responsibility of the SN-OD/SR and the Consultant in charge to document all discussions and their outcomes with family/NOK in the patient's medical and nursing notes.
Consent for donation
Organ and tissue retrieval is governed by the Human Tissue Act  and regulated by the Human Tissue Authority (HTA 2004).
Following public consultation, the Organ Donation (Deemed Consent) Bill received Royal Assent on the 15th March 2019 and was passed in to law on the 20th May 2020.

The Deemed Consent Act (also known as “Opt out”) means that, in England, all individuals over 18 are considered potential organ and tissue donors after death, unless they make a decision about organ donation, they have nominated a representative to make a decision on their behalf after death or they are an excepted adult. Deemed consent will only apply to certain organs and tissue: the list of organs and tissue excluded from deemed consent is set out in the Human Tissue (Permitted Material: Exceptions) (England) Regulations 2020.
Excluded groups:
Those under the age of
People who lack the mental capacity to understand the new arrangements and take the necessary action
Visitors to England and those not living here voluntarily (i.e. Prisoners).
People who have lived in England for less than 12 months before their death
Under the law donation will still be discussed with families to ensure that the most up to date individual decisions are known and respected.

The HTA Code lists the relationships which are deemed as appropriate to involve in discussions about donation. The following list represents the qualifying relationships in descending order that should be involved in the discussions. The person ranked highest in the list should be identified and consent sought.
Spouse or partner (including civil or same sex partner)
Parent or child
Brother or sister
Grandparent or grandchild
Niece or nephew
Stepfather or stepmother
Half-brother or half sister
Friend of longstanding

Where there is a signed donor card or registration on the NHS Organ Donor Register this represents consent of the individual for donation and as such is sufficient consent for donation to be lawful (HTA 2004). In such cases it is the responsibility of the SNOD/SR in collaboration with the Consultant to inform the deceased person's relative or those close to them of the deceased person's decision and confirm that this is the patient's last known decision.

On the rare occasion where the patient has consented and the person who is ranked highest in the qualifying relationships (see above) declines the option of donation, an agreed position should be reached by inclusive discussion with the family/NOK, ICU/Anaesthetic Consultant and SN-OD. The Family should be encouraged to accept the decision of the deceased. There may, of course, be situations in which donation is inappropriate and each family should be considered individually. It would be very unusual to proceed if the family have expressed direct opposition to donation however, they have no legal right to veto the decisions of the patient(DeJong, Franz et al. 1998).

In the case of a child (<18 yrs.) who has registered on the NHS Organ Donor Register, it is the responsibility of the SN-OD to discuss with those who have parental responsibility for the child and take their views into consideration before deciding how to proceed. Enquiries should be made as to the competence of the child at the time of registering.

In the case of a child <18 years of age who has not registered on the NHS Organ Donor Register, consent must be obtained from the person with parental responsibility. Where there are 2 individuals with equal responsibility, consent must be obtained from one.
Under deemed consent, in cases where there are no relatives or friends to confirm the existence of a most recent known decision, then donation cannot proceed.
Documenting consent

It is the responsibility of the SN-OD/SR to obtain a signature from the nominated representative or qualifying person to confirm their consent having first provided information on the donation process. A copy of the NHSBT consent and Assessment form together with a detailed description of the discussions undertaken should be filed in the patient's medical notes.

In situations where they are unable to sign e.g. living abroad or communicating via the telephone it is acceptable for the SN-OD/SR who is taking the consent to document the details in the patient's notes. A second person should be available to listen to the conversation and sign to confirm they have witnessed this, and where possible the conversation will be recorded.
Religious perspectives

All major religions support the principles of organ donation and transplantation. It is recognised that within each religion there are different schools of thought, which means  that  the  views  of  individuals  may  differ.  Referral  to  the  Eastern  Organ Donation Services Team should be made regardless of the patients' religion. It should not be assumed that because a patient or their family come from a specific religious background that referral for donation should not be made.
Information leaflets regarding individual religions and organ donation are available on the NHSBT Organ Donation & Transplant web site (NHSBT 2020).
Ethnicity

The need for an organ transplant in the black and minority ethnic (BAME) community is more than three times higher than that of the general population. A transplant is much more likely to be successful if the donor and recipient have the same ethnic background. In accordance with equality and diversity requirements it is essential that potential donors from all ethnic backgrounds are referred to the Eastern Organ Donation Services Team. It should not be assumed that because a patient or their family come from a specific ethnic background that referral for donation should not be made.
ProfessionalGuidance

The General Medical Council specifically addresses issues relating to organ donation in the document “Treatment and Care towards the end of life” (2010). This document states that medical staff “should follow any national procedures for identifying potential organ donors” and “for notifying the local transplant coordinator”
The organ donor register (ODR)

The Organ Donor Register can be accessed by the SN-OD / SR 24 hours a day. Where an individual has joined the ODR, the registration will detail the date and mode of joining and any restrictions specified by the individual. This is accepted as first person consent. If requested the SN-OD / SR can provide a printed copy of the ODR registration for the donor family. A printed copy of the ODR registration will be included in the NHSBT file of any proceeding donor. After donation the ODR cannot be consulted retrospectively as the details of any deceased individuals are removed. The ODR will not be consulted until a clear plan regarding withdrawal of treatment or DDNC has been recorded – as earlier knowledge of the ODR status may be perceived to have an influence on care or treatment decisions. All patients should be considered for donation regardless of ODR status.
Suspected brain stem death

With regards to patients presenting with devastating brain injuries a period of physiological stabilisation and observation is recommended to improve the quality of decision making as prognostication at the time of initial admission can be inaccurate (Harvey, D et al, 2018) . Where DDNC is suspected or anticipated, the patient should be actively managed and maintained for formal testing. The Intensive Care Society Guidelines (2004) recommends that Diagnosis of Death by Neurological Criteria should be performed in all cases where neurological death is suspected.

Reasonable and where necessary invasive clinical measures should be taken to stabilise such patients to allow testing to take place. Testing should be performed according to the strict guidelines laid down in the Diagnosis and Confirmation of Death Guidelines (Academy of Medical Royal Colleges 2008). https://www.ficm.ac.uk/sites/default/files/form_for_the_diagnosis_of_death_using_n eurological_criteria_-_long_version_nov_2019_003.pdf

DDNC testing should be considered to be unrelated to organ donation and the subject of donation is not usually raised until DDNC tests have been completed and DDNC has been confirmed. This should be assessed on an individual basis through a collaborative discussion as on occasions it may be appropriate to discuss the possibility of Organ Donation prior to testing.
It is both lawful and ethically acceptable to take reasonable measures to clinically stabilise and maintain an individual while their decision regarding organ donation are explored or fulfilled.
Temperature should be normalised. DDNC testing cannot be performed in individuals where the temperature is below  degrees centigrade.
Where therapeutic hypothermia has been induced it is recommended that DDNC tests should not be performed until 24 hours after normothermia has been achieved.

Blood pressure should be supported, and central access should be cited to facilitate the administration of inotropic agents if required to maintain cardiovascular stability and a MAP above  mmHg during DDNC tests or discussions regarding organ donation.
Fluid balance should be maintained with output matched by fluid replacement. The administration of DDAVP (Desmopressin) should be considered to control diuresis if Diabetes Insipidus is suspected.

Electrolytes should be maintained within normal limits as marked elevation or deficiency will preclude DDNC testing. The acceptable range is detailed within the Diagnosis and Confirmation of Death Guidelines (Academy of Medical Royal Colleges – 2008).
If consent for cardiothoracic donation is given the SN-OD / SR will request permission to mobilise a “Donor Management Scout Team”.
Donor optimisation

It is widely considered that it is both morally and ethically sound, to manage the patient based upon the assumption that they are a potential organ donor prior to the consent process. If consent or other issues subsequently preclude organ donation then withdrawal of organ support will be undertake.

Prior to and following consent for donation it is the responsibility of the Consultant, the SN-OD/SR and those caring for the deceased to optimise organ perfusion in accordance with the Intensive Care Society Guidelines on the clinical management of the potential heart beating organ donor. Transplant centres may also provide additional advice. The Donor Optimisation Extended care bundle should be utilised for all brain stem dead patients (to be provided by the SNOD/SR).
Donor optimisation guideline for management of the brain-stem dead donor; available online via  https://www.odt.nhs.uk/deceased-donation/best-practice- guidance/donor-optimisation/
Protocol for donation after brain stem death (DBD)
(Appendix B)
If it is suspected that the patient is brain stem dead or is likely to become brain stem dead the ITU Consultant will be responsible for their management.

Unless the family / next of kin initiate discussion about donation the option should not be discussed until such time as brain stem death testing has been carried out and the family / next of kin fully understand that death has occurred.
The family / next of kin will be fully informed of the plan to brain stem death test and the nature of the tests.
Testing will be carried out in line with national guidance: A Code of Practice for the Diagnosis and Confirmation of Death (The Academy of Medical Royal Colleges 2008).
Date and time of death is pronounced and documented following completion of the first set of tests.

Understanding that death has occurred in a warm, heart-beating, ventilated patient is sometimes very difficult for family members to understand. In these cases it may be useful for some family members to witness the tests being done. If this is the case, unless they insist on witnessing both sets of tests, it could be suggested that they watch the second set of tests (confirmatory set) or just the apnoea test. The SN-OD/SR will consult with the Nurse in Charge and Consultants undertaking the tests before approaching the family about witnessing the testing. A member of staff must be able to support the family and explain what is being done throughout.

The SN-OD/SR (where possible) will be present during pre-testing and post testing discussions with the family. Research has shown that the earlier the SN-OD/SR is involved with the family the higher the consent rate.
Once the clinical staff and SN-OD/SR have established that the time is right to approach the family for donation the SN-OD/SR will be available to answer any questions and explain the process.
If the family decline donation, withdrawal of life sustaining treatment will take place as decided by the doctor. Where required the SN-OD/SR will stay to support the family and staff.
If the family wish to proceed with donation the SN-OD/SR will take consent and coordinate the donation process through to completion.
The SN-OD and CLOD will offer debrief sessions for all staff involved within two weeks of donation. A follow-up letter will also be sent to those involved with the donation within15 working days.
Donation after Circulatory death (DCD) (Appendix C)

DCD involves critically ill patients in whom it is decided that continued treatment is futile and that withdrawal of life-sustaining treatment is in the patient's best interests. Death is based upon circulatory criteria instead of neurological criteria and following the confirmation of death the patient may be eligible to become a DCD donor.
Any decision regarding withdrawal of life sustaining treatment:
Should be carried out in accordance with national guidelines, as published by the General Medical Council and the Intensive Care Society, and in accordance with local best practice and guidelines.
https://www.gmc-uk.org/-/media/documents/ Treatment_and_care_towards_the_end_of_life English_1015.pdf_48902105.pdf
Must be completely and demonstrably independent, and uninfluenced by any consideration regarding organ donation.

A valid Do Not Attempt Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (DNACPR) order and Treatment Escalation Plan (TEP), as per Trust policy should be included in the medical records, as should a documented intention to withdraw life sustaining treatment.

It is both lawful and ethically acceptable to take reasonable measures to clinically stabilise and maintain an individual while their decision regarding organ donation is explored or fulfilled. Treatment should not be withdrawn or limited until a clear decision with regard to organ donation has been agreed. The comfort and care needs of the patient remain paramount throughout the donation process and it is essential that sedative drugs or analgesics are not withheld in patients who are to progress to donation after circulatory death.
Organ donation from the emergency department

Emergency Departments have a role to play in increasing organ donation through the robust identification of those patients whose catastrophic brain injuries (medical or traumatic) are clearly not survivable. In these circumstances, rather than have life sustaining treatment withdrawn immediately, staff should follow the NICE guidelines and refer to the SNOD / SR so that their wishes can be established.

The decision to withdraw active support follows best medical practice and would usually be a joint decision involving ED medical staff and Critical Care medical staff with/without advice from neurosurgery and in the patient's best interest.

In recognition of time restrictions that are specific to ED it is recommended that a provisional referral is made at the earliest indication of any unsurvivable condition where the patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated. This will allow a SN- OD / SR to initiate early mobilisation to Mid South Essex NHS FT or to rule out the potential for organ donation in collaboration with transplant surgeons.

In the case of a provisional referral, all care and investigations should continue as they would in a case where organ donation had not been considered, including referral to Critical Care and Neurosurgery.
Should the ceiling of care be reached, life-sustaining treatment should not be withdrawn until the potential for organ donation has been fully explored.

The location of a patient's death should not prevent organ donation from occurring. It is in the best interests of the patient that they be cared for in a Critical Care environment to allow a full assessment of their clinical and broader interests, including the donation potential, by staff that have the appropriate skills and knowledge to do so. This includes the proper care of the dying patient and their relatives. Organ donation is likely to be a relatively infrequent event.

When a patient in the ED is identified as a potential organ donor, consultation should take place between the ED Consultant and the Critical Care Consultant so that resources available at that particular time are reviewed and an agreed plan to facilitate donation is made.
Should the patient's prognosis improve or if there is a subsequent plan to transfer the patient for neurosurgery the SN-OD / SR should be informed, they will then ‘stand down'.

If following referral to the Organ Donation Services Team a potential for donation is established the patient should be stabilised in an appropriate Critical Care setting until the SNOD / SR is in attendance and full assessment for donation is undertaken.

There may be occasions, for example, extreme capacity issues, when it is more suitable for the patient to be moved directly to an appropriate critical care area from the ED and cared for by an anaesthetist or member of the Critical Care Nursing staff. Alternatively, it may be necessary for the patient to remain in the ED where it is likely a model of shared care would be most appropriate. A flexible collaborative approach is needed to determine the most appropriate facility.

If the patient is not accepted for admission to Critical Care the responsibility for the care of the patient remains that of the ED and all decisions regarding the ongoing care of the patient should be made by an ED clinician with the support of the ITU team.

In order to ensure Trust compliance with NICE Guideline CG135, every patient fulfilling notification criteria should be referred to the Organ Donation Services Team regardless of their location in the hospital.
Staffing and Capacity

Any patient who has been identified as a potential organ donor in the ED and where donation potential has been confirmed by a SN-OD/SR, should be admitted to a suitable Critical Care area for maintenance and stabilisation

Admission to Critical Care should be facilitated if there is an available bed. If there is only one bed available, negotiations should take place between the SN- OD/ SR Critical care consultant and ED consultant.

If there are no Critical Care beds the SN-OD/ SR/ ED Staff / Critical Care Consultant and Staff should in the first instance contact the on call Site Manager who will undertake to transfer patients appropriately to realise capacity for admission of the potential donor.
If a Critical Care bed cannot be identified the patient should remain in the ED and treatment maintained.
If admission is limited by staffing issues, all measures should be taken to identify and utilise a suitably trained nurse to provide direct care to the potential donor.

It is professionally and ethically unacceptable for a SN-OD/ SR to be responsible for the provision of direct care for a potential donor prior to death, other than by assisting Mid South Essex NHS FT staff in delivering basic nursing care.
Coronial Involvement

All potential organ donors will be referred to HM Coroner. This will be done by the SN-OD/SR and clinician together, after approaching the family and gaining their verbal consent to donation. The Coroner has the ultimate decision in these cases and may place restrictions on what can be donated. The SN-OD/ SR will arrange this. The Coroner has a legal duty and must be informed in every case where death is not due to entirely natural causes. If there is any doubt it is the Coroner's and not the doctor's decision, the case should be referred. If the doctor requesting coronial authorisation for organ and / or tissue donation has not treated the deceased in their last illness, he or she should contact a member of the medical team who treated the deceased during their last illness.

In all cases, the coroner is responsible for the final decision as to whether a donation goes ahead. Organ or tissue donation cannot proceed without the agreement of the Coroner who must be satisfied that the donation will not interfere with his / her duty to investigate the death. It is important to realise that in such cases, although the Coroner must agree to donation, the Coroner has no power to authorise donation.

A principal concern of Coroners is to ensure that any forensic examination or criminal proceedings arising from the death are not compromised by the retrieval of organs or other interference with the body. Before giving permission in a particular case, where criminal proceedings are likely, it is important that the Coroner discusses the case with the pathologist (forensic or otherwise) who will be carrying out the post mortem examination and the senior police investigating officer. The Coroner may also ask for a forensic pathologist to be present at the retrieval or that photographs are taken or witness statements are obtained from the retrieving surgeons. This may mean that donation can proceed where otherwise it may not have been possible. Provided such procedures are followed and there is an appropriate consent either from the donor or from an individual in a qualifying relationship, the Coroner should have no reason to object to organ or tissue donation in most circumstances. Even in deaths entailing guidelines laid down in the Diagnosis of Death Guidelines (Academy of Medical Royal Coleges, 2008)

In the case of a police investigation, if full information is provided, the Coroner, in consultation with the police, may be able to agree to donation of some organs and / or tissues. However, in such cases, the SN-OD/SR will contact the pathologist and senior police investigating officer, in addition to the coroner as soon as possible (DH 2010a).

All conversations with the Coroner or Coroner's Officer must be recorded in the deceased's medical records. The SN-OD / SR will ensure that the Coroners consent for the removal of organs for transplantation has been obtained where required and documented (Standards of Practice for SN-OD 2010).
Positive virology

Blood samples for virology testing and tissue typing are taken from every potential donor in order to ascertain suitability as outlined above. These samples are tested on behalf of the transplant teams in laboratories outside the Trust. The results are made available to the transplant teams. If the results of any samples tested negate donation for reasons that could potentially impact on the health and wellbeing of the next of kin / significant others the senior clinician (at MSE) and SN-OD /SR has a duty of care to ensure they are made aware of this possibility. Permission to collect these samples and to perform these blood tests is sought and recorded within the consent process.

Any positive virology results will be managed collaboratively by Mid South Essex FT and NHSBT according to NHSBT documents MPD 942 and Policy 108/1 to ensure the safety of any transplant recipients or potential transplant recipients.

Novel Infectious Diseases: The emergence of new infectious diseases, especially in the context of a global pandemic may require adaption of these guidelines. For example in the case of Covid – 19 the following will be taken: nose and throat swabs, Endotracheal aspirate and blood samples. These samples are tested on behalf of the transplant teams in laboratories outside the Trust. The results are made available to the transplant teams.
Family follow up

The SN-OD /SR is available to support the family in the first days, weeks and months following the death. A follow up letter is also sent to the family one year after the death. The SN-OD/SR will refer to other agencies as appropriate and provide contact details of the Eastern Organ Donation Services Team in Cambridge. The SN-OD/SR will ensure that the donation and transplantation outcome is communicated to the family of all donors, within 15 working days of the donation, unless the family request otherwise. In cases of tissue only donation, the tissue coordinator will contact the family to confirm which tissues have been retrieved. The SN-OD/SR will ensure that outcome feedback is provided to staff within 15 working days of the donation. The SN-OD/SR may seek service feedback evaluation from healthcare professionals involved in the donation process. The SN- OD/SR will ensure any relevant issue or incident is discussed with the CLOD and where necessary the Trust Board and / or Organ and Tissue Donation Committee and followed up as agreed (NHSBT 2010).
Conscientious objection

Clinical staff who have conscientious objections to donation cannot be expected to take part in the process, but neither can their objection be allowed to deny any patient or their family the opportunity of donation when it involves a process that has received local and national endorsement (Murphy & Logan 2009).

Conscientious objection may be permissible if sufficient medical and nursing staff are available and willing to provide the service. Conscientious objectors must ensure that patients and their families are aware of the care they are entitled to and should refer care to another suitable professional to facilitate the process. Conscientious objectors must not compromise the care of their patients, (Savulescu 2006).
Confidentiality
Unless advised to the contrary by those identified above, information will not be released to the press or media. (Refer to Trust policy for dealing with press and media).
Theatre process

A suitable time will be negotiated between the theatre coordinator, anaesthetist and SNOD /SR taking into account theatre availability, donor stability, family and recipient centre requirements. Trust responsibilities:
Theatre staff will ensure that:
The donor hospital will provide a fully equipped operating theatre for the retrieval procedure, including appropriate anaesthetic equipment and drugs to support the donor.
The theatre should be set up with suction (2 X 4 chamber), diathermy, lights and trolleys
The retrieval team(s) are greeted and shown where to change and where to put equipment (designated theatre).
A member of staff (runner/ODP) is available to support the retrieval team
A member of staff is available to undertake last offices along with the SN-OD
Anaesthetic Support:
In cases of DCD an anaesthetist will be required to:
Transfer the patient to the anaesthetic room
Assist with withdrawal of support by discontinuing cardiovascular medications and extubate the patient.
Certify death
Re-intubate for lung re-inflation prior to lung retrieval (if required)
In cases of DDNC an anaesthetist will be required to:
Transfer the patient to theatre
Maintain the patient until cross-clamp
Where the cardio-thoracic team has brought its own donor physiologist, be available to give support if required.
Retrieval team responsibilities:
National Organ Retrieval Guidelines (2015) state that:
The SN-OD/SR must ensure that the pre theatre section of the FRM4135 NHSBT Surgical Safety Checklist is completed before the start of the retrieval operation.
The SN-OD/SR will maintain a presence in theatre to ensure continued coordination of the retrieval process.
Before embarking on the retrieval operation, the lead retrieval surgeons should review the patient notes. In particular they must check:
The identity, blood group and virology status of the donor;
That brain stem death or confirmation of cardiac death has been confirmed and documented correctly;
That appropriate consent/authorisation has been obtained for the organs and tissues to be retrieved;
All aspects of the retrieval operation should be conducted in accordance with appropriate infection control procedures.

(Novel Infectious Diseases: The emergence of new infectious diseases, especially in the context of a global pandemic may require adaption of these guidelines. While it is unlikely that a patient who is dying as a result of a new infectious disease to be accepted as an organ donation, consideration of the risk to family and staff members needs to be taken. Extubation and the use of bone saws are classed as aerosol generating procedures and as such may require additional PPE measures for staff. In this case it may be appropriate to limit the number of staff within the operating theatre and not permissible for family members to be present during the withdrawal of treatment. All decisions should be made in conjunction of the intensive care consultant and local infection control teams.
Members of the retrieval team should be aware that they are ambassadors for transplantation and must behave in a professional manner throughout the retrieval process.
Retrieval teams must work to agreed protocols during the retrieval procedure.

On completion of the operation, the lead surgeon from each team is responsible for producing an accurate operation record in the donor patient notes. This should include clear documentation of all organs and tissues removed from the body, a note of any abnormalities/injuries noted during laparotomy or thoracotomy, and the time of respiratory and/or cardiac arrest.
DCD: Process of withdrawal

When consent and associated arrangements for organ donation are in place the surgical retrieval team will attend and prepare for surgery. Treatment should be continued until the SN-OD /SR advises that the surgical team is ready to commence surgery.

The location of withdrawal of life sustaining treatment will be discussed but ideally it should take place in the anaesthetic room (exception for Colne Ward, BTUH, where withdrawal will take place on the unit). This will enable a controlled transfer of the body into theatre after death has been pronounced.
The retrieval team(s) will be scrubbed and waiting quietly in theatre when withdrawal takes place

The anaesthetic room will be prepared by the theatre staff with the assistance of the SN-OD /SR to remove any unnecessary equipment, cover windows and arrange chairs for the accompanying family / NOK.

The patient will be brought to the anaesthetic room with monitoring in place and, once the family, staff and retrieval team are ready, withdrawal of life sustaining support will occur. Any analgesia or sedation that is being used for patient comfort measures will continue as planned / prescribed and titrated.
The nurse caring for the patient will remain with the patient, the family / NOK and the SN-OD /SR. The patient will be kept comfortable throughout.

The SN-OD/SR will be responsible for monitoring the patient, liaising with the retrieval team(s) in the theatre and ensuring that the retrieval teams remain quiet at all times. The SN-OD/ SR will also assist with reassurance of the family / NOK.
Withdrawal of treatment should not be undertaken until a suitable medical practitioner has been identified and is available to certify death 5 minutes after loss of circulation.

It is appropriate to diagnose death 5 minutes after loss of the central pulses, loss of arterial pressure and the loss of heart sounds. For the purpose of organ donation the time of death should be documented as at loss of the arterial line trace / loss of cardiac output as opposed to the loss of agonal, electrical activity on the ECG trace.
If the donor family elects to be present at certification of death the ECG monitor should be removed and heart rate monitored via the arterial line trace.
In order to facilitate organ donation the patient will be transferred to theatre immediately after certification of death and surgery will proceed immediately.

The family should be given the opportunity to remain with the patient who is a potential DCD donor up until the time that they are transferred to theatre. After this time the family will be taken back to Critical Care Unit / Emergency Department relatives' room by the accompanying nurse and supported until such time as they go home. The department staff will ensure that the family / NOK have all the relevant paperwork they need and know when to contact the bereavement office.

The family must be made aware that organ donation cannot proceed if death does not  occur  within  the  agreed  timeframe  following  withdrawal  of  life  sustaining treatment  (generally  up  to  four  hours  post  withdrawal).  If  the  patient  does not proceed to donation an area suitable for appropriate end of life care should be identified  and  the  patient  should  be  transferred  to  this  area  when  the  non- proceeding donation process is completed.

If the patient had not previously been under the care of a specified consultant or team, an appropriate clinical specialty will be identified and approached to take ongoing responsibility for the care of the patient.
Tissueonly donors

The quality of life for many people can be improved by the transplantation of tissues such as corneas (to restore sight), bone, blood vessels, meniscus, tendon, skin (to treat  burns)  or  heart  valves  (to  treat  acquired  cardiac  disorders  or  congenital malformations). Tissue does not deteriorate immediately following cessation of the heart beat due to its low metabolic requirements, allowing more time for tissue retrieval.

Tissue  donation  can  be  facilitated  from  ALL  wards  and  units  following  cardio- respiratory death. Unlike solid organs, which are considered life-saving, the majority of tissues are considered to be life-enhancing and therefore there are stricter criteria applied  to  assessing  tissue  donations.  Each  individual  will  be  assessed  by  a specialist nurse from NHSBT Tissue Services to establish their suitability to be donor.
Referral to tissue services
(Refer to appendix D)

Following the death of the patient the family may be approached by a Mid South Essex  NHS  FT  based  doctor  or  nurse  to establish  whether  tissue  donation is something they would wish to consider.

The family may bring the subject up themselves and the staff must be able to facilitate their wishes. If the family indicate that they would consider tissue donation, they should be advised that a specialist nurse from Tissue Services will telephone them at home later in the day to discuss the patient's past medical and social history, and to gain consent if donation is possible.

The member of staff (doctor or nurse) will page Tissue Services on: 0800 4320559. A member of staff from Tissue Services will reply to the person making the referral and gather details of the patient. The patient's notes will be needed to ensure all information is given. The next of kin telephone number and the GP details will be required.  Out  of  hours  a  message  may  be  taken  and  the  Tissue  Services coordinator may phone the ward in the morning.

Normal end of life care procedures should be carried out as per hospital policy and the staff should ensure that the patient's body has two name bands and is transferred to the mortuary within six hours of death. The bereavement services team and mortuary staff must be informed that the patient may be a tissue donor. If the death occurs at night, they must be contacted as soon as the offices open. If the patient is not suitable to be a tissue donor the ward staff may be told immediately and can give this information sensitively to the family if they are still in the department. If the family have gone home, the member of staff may ask the Tissue Services coordinator to contact the family to let them know or may phone the family themselves, if they feel comfortable to do so. Tissue donation is carried out in the mortuary by trained Tissue retrieval staff. Tissues must be retrieved within 24 hours of death (in exceptional circumstances some tissues may be retrieved up to 48 hours). Corneas must be retrieved within 24 hours of death. Tissue donation does not prevent a body being viewed by the family. Families will be fully informed by the Tissue Services staff of any changes to the appearance of the body.
Whole body donation

An individual may wish to leave their body to a school of anatomy. This decision must have been made by the donor in life with full capacity and registered with a school of anatomy. The donor would inform the designated individual who has the responsibility to contact the relevant school of anatomy and inform them of the donor's death. At this point suitability would be assessed by the school of anatomy. The Bereavement office will be able to provide further advice on this if required. Some patients may still be able to donate corneas for transplantation.
Training requirements

All staff who may become involved in organ donation will have received training in organ donation and will receive annual update training by the in house SN-OD/ SR. Staff will be supported by the Organ Donation Services team during the actual process The SN-OD / SR is available to provide educational sessions for all grades and disciplines of staff. Education relating to organ donation should be considered essential for all members of trust staff who are involved in the care of potential organ or tissue donors. (NICE guideline 135, 2011)
Monitoring and audit

The SN-OD will undertake a monthly potential donor audit of all patients who die within ED or ITU. Any cases of missed referrals will be investigated by the SNOD and the Clinical lead informed. The SN-OD will monitor rates of potential organ donor identification, referral, and approach to the family and consent to donation. The SN-OD will report the monthly data to the Chairman, CLOD, Director of Nursing, Medical Director for each hospital within Mid South Essex NHS FT in the absence of the CLOD. The Organ Donation Committee will report six monthly to the Mid South Essex Boards through the usual Clinical governance process and the Medical Directors. Benchmark data will be made available for comparison. The data will be held by NHSBT who will monitor it each month. A 6 monthly report will be compiled by NHSBT comparing local and national data based on the potential donor audit data supplied and they will provide Mid South Essex NHS FT hospitals with a benchmark against national performance. This report will be sent directly to the Chief Executive and Medical Director.

The Organ Donation Committees will ensure that if the Mid South Essex NHS FT Board  are required  to  provide  evidence  on  organ  donation  within  the  Trust  to National bodies such as the CQC they are assured of compliance with the:
Department of Health's Organ Donation ‘A Code of Practice including the Diagnosis of Brain Death, Cadaveric Organs for Transplantation',
Healthcare Commission's Outcome 1, Regulation 17, ‘Respecting and Involving People who use the service'
NHS Constitution Real Involvement Working with People To Improve Health Services

Compliance with the Human Tissue Authority (HTA) and requirements of the Human Tissue Act 2004 (HT Act), The Human Tissue Act 2004 (Ethical Approval, Exceptions from licensing and Supply of Information about Transplants) Regulations 2006

Delivery of the Patient Involvement & Experience Strategy 2007 – 2010, Ensuring a Voice: Offering Choice (currently being updated) targets and implementation of recommendations arising from patient surveys.
The Group's Minutes will be circulated by Group Members to all interested Groups/Committees
